_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The five qualities of a mendicant who is: Conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places
Seeing danger in the slightest fault and keeping the rules they’ve undertaken
Being very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned
The teachings that the mendicant is very: These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end
Describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure
Being very learned in such teachings, remembering them, reinforcing them by recitation, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically
The contentment of the mendicant (a item: Contentment with any kind of robes
Contentment with any kind of almsfood
Contentment with any kind of lodgings
Contentment with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick
The attainments of the mendicant [an5.10: The realization of the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life
Living having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
